channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Uber Driver in New Delhi, Accused of Rape, Faces Other Charges
item.description: Shiv Kumar Yadav, the cabdriver accused of raping a female passenger in New Delhi over the weekend, was free on bail in at least three other serious criminal cases, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: U.N. Food Agency to Resume Suspended Aid to Syrian Refugees
item.description: An emergency appeal through social media brought an outpouring of donations for the World Food Program, which the agency’s director called unprecedented.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: C.I.A. Kept Bush Ill Informed on Interrogation Tactics, Torture Report Says
item.description: President Bush knew few details of the harsh interrogation tactics used by the C.I.A., which also misrepresented its successes, the Senate Intelligence Committee report says.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: George J. Tenet, center, the director of the C.I.A., in March 2003 with President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney.

item.title: Senate Torture Report Shows C.I.A. Infighting Over Interrogation Program
item.description: The Senate Intelligence Committee’s report paints a devastating picture of an agency that was ill equipped to question terrorism suspects, bungled the job and misrepresented the results.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: The report from the Senate Intelligence Committee rebuts claims that torture yielded critical information that helped disrupt terrorist plots and capture terrorist leaders.

item.title: Senate Torture Report Condemns C.I.A. Interrogation Program
item.description: The scathing report, which took five years to produce, is a sweeping indictment of the C.I.A.'s operation and oversight of an interrogation program carried out in secret prisons after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: The Senate report describes the waterboarding of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed as a "series of near drownings."

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Day Among the Protesters’ Tents in Hong Kong
item.description: On Tuesday, Sinosphere will explore Hong Kong’s last major remaining protest camp and ask people there about the demonstrations and their legacy.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Tents set up by pro-democracy protesters blocking a main road outside Hong Kong's government headquarters in the Admiralty district. Some of the protest banners read “Support the students,” “I want genuine universal suffrage” and “Civil disobedience.”

item.title: Elena Ferrante, Author of Naples Novels, Stays Mysterious
item.description: Elena Ferrante, the popular Italian author whose identity has never been revealed, talks about her Naples novels and her reasons for anonymity.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:credit: Chris Warde-Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sandra Ozzola and Sandro Ferri of Edizioni E/O, the Italian publisher of Elena Ferrante's books.

item.title: Protesters and Police Clash Amid Vote in Northern India
item.description: The third phase of voting in Jammu and Kashmir State, in contrast with the first two, was marked by a familiar pattern of limited turnout and stone-throwing.
item.dc:creator: By SAMEER YASIR and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: French Hostage, Kidnapped by Islamic Militants in 2011, Is Freed
item.description: President François Hollande said Serge Lazarevic had been the last French hostage anywhere in the world.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Greek Premier Moves Forward With Call to Speed Up Presidential Elections
item.description: The decision, announced after an extension to the eurozone bailout program was granted, could usher in a leftist party opposed to austerity measures.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: German Court Finds Insufficient Evidence Linking Ex-Soldier to Nazi Massacre
item.description: A ruling cites a lack of proof that an 89-year-old former SS gunner participated in the 1944 killings at Oradour-sur-Glane, France.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Hong Kong Police Announce Plan to Clear Main Protest Site
item.description: A police spokesman said officers would mobilize to remove blockades in the protest camp and urged demonstrators to leave the site as soon as possible.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Another Anti-Polio Worker Is Killed in Pakistan
item.description: The shooting in Faisalabad was the latest attack on a health care worker amid the government’s struggle to contain the disease.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: At Climate Meeting, China Balks at Verifying Cuts in Carbon Emissions
item.description: Officials have sometimes referred to a 24-year-old clause that says countries should have “common but differentiated responsibilities,” meaning developed and developing nations have different standards to meet when it comes to taking action on climate change.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Smog obscures the skyline in Shenyang, Liaoning Province. Populist anger over toxic smog has convinced some Chinese leaders that carbon emissions need to be curbed.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Attacks Army Headquarters in Yemen
item.description: At least five Yemeni soldiers were killed when two suicide bombers tried to drive cars laden with explosives into a military compound in the country’s east.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: South African Prosecutors Start Push to Appeal Pistorius’s Sentence
item.description: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa, who conducted the Pistorius trial, listened to the arguments for and against an appeal and said she would respond Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Fernando Cheung Chiu-hung on the Hong Kong Protests’ Legacy
item.description: Fernando Cheung Chiu-hung, one of the democratic members of the Hong Kong Legislative Council, has been heavily involved in attempting to defuse confrontations during the city’s pro-democracy protest movement.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Fernando Cheung Chiu-hung, a democratic member of the Legislative Council, says the people of Hong Kong have been awakened and will continue to call for true democracy.

item.title: Q. and A. About the C.I.A. Torture Report
item.description: Information about the Senate Intelligence Committee’s account of C.I.A. tactics and its possible ramifications.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: Members of the George W. Bush administration began to challenge the conclusions of the Senate report before it was released.

item.title: Turks Feud Over Change in Education
item.description: The president of Turkey wants Ottoman Turkish taught to schoolchildren, a plan that has drawn widespread criticism from parents and political opponents.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: French Holocaust Survivors Promise to Fight Exclusion From New Reparations
item.description: A $60 million accord for victims transported to concentration camps by the French national railway is facing criticism for leaving out French citizens.
item.category: SNCF (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
